Let's talk about Julia!
Chances are you hadn't heard about Julia until now. It's a shiny new programming language, and hasn't yet become widely used. Maybe you're interested in using it for a new project, or maybe you just want to learn a new language. Whatever the case, you're in the right place!

💭 When and why was R made? Who contributed to the development of this language?

Julia was begun in 2009 by Jeff Bezanson, Stefan Karpinski, Viral B. Shah, and Alan Edelman, with the purpose of creating a free high-level language that was fast, and the language is especially useful for computational science problems. The creators of Julia received the James H. Wilkinson Prize for Numerical Software in 2019, and Alan Edelman (a professor at MIT) received the IEEE Computer Society Sidney Fernbach Award for his contributions to Julia among other things. Julia version 0.7 and 1.0 were both released on August 8, 2018. Since then, Julia 1.1 to 1.9.3 have been released, although version 1.7.x is no longer supported.

Julia has hosted an annual Julia conference (JuliaCon) since 2014 which has taken place in several places across the United States and even online in 2020. With important contributors to computer science giving keynote speeches at the event.

📗 What classes at Wellesley use this language?

Julia is entirely open source and very general-purpose, although it was designed for strong numerical computing. It is also good for low-level systems programming, as a specification language (description of a system’s capabilities), High-level Synthesis (HLS) tool and web programming. Julia functions as a dynamic language but it still manages to run at a speed comparable to static languages. It has multiple dispatch functionality, meaning you can name several functions the same thing with different arguments (or argument types). Julia has just-in-time compilation and supports ahead-of-time compilation as well. It also includes package management and allows users to use libraries from Python, R, C, C++, and Java.

Some additional functionality include:

  • Macros (writing programs that operate on programs, i.e., metaprogramming)
  • Efficient parallel computing (with GPU support)
  • Flexibility in self-extension (eg. users can make their own primitive data types)
  • Machine transparency
  • Supports C object code anywhere in the program
  • Green threads (coroutines)
  • Jupyter support

In a nutshell, Julia is a fast, dynamic, general-purpose programming language with the ability to easily interface with other programming languages. Compared to Python it will often be slightly faster because it can compile directly to machine code, and it has much more accessible meta-programming capabilities. Compared to C++ or Java, it supports type inference and generally does not require type declarations; like Java it has a garbage collector. However, Julia does not have classes or multiple inheritance, and relies on multiple-dispatch at the function level to handle object-oriented style programming.

IDEs

Here is a list of some of the IDEs that support Julia (may need extensions to function):

  • VS code
  • IJulia (Jupyter)
  • IntelliJ
  • Pluto.jl
  • PyCharm
  • JuliaBox (browser-based)
  • Sublime

General purpose text editors like Vim or Emacs will also work, and have extensions for Julia.

General Syntax

Julia syntax is very similar to Python. Let’s take a look at some simple code!

Print Statement:

println(“Hello World!”)

Variable Declaration:

Variable names are case sensitive and tend to be written all lowercase with underscores between words (note that lowerCamelCase is considered more accessible).

my_string = “string”
my_int = 1
my_float = 2.6

Comments:

# Single line comments denoted with a hash
#= multi line comments
    Denoted with a hash-equals at the start
    And an equals-hash at the end.
=#

Function Definition:

function name(arg1, arg2, … )
    # function code
    return result1, result2, …
end

Or for one line functions:

function_name(arg1, arg2) = # function code

If-Else Statements:

if  # boolean_expression
    # Inner code
elseif  # boolean_expression
    # Inner code
else
    # Inner code
end

Loops:

For Loop

for i in 1:10
    println(i)
end

While Loop

n=0
while n<3
    global n +=1
end

Further Readings

There are many other aspects of Julia you can explore if you're interested in it that make it unique from other languages, such as the wide array of operators it supports and its matrix support. Feel free to check out more of these details in these resources!

  • Julia Website
